poem:
**The Unpoundland**

Once every item wore a halo,  
leaning into the singular song of one coin.  
Now the aisles stretch long with inflation's echo,  
shelves whispering promises they no longer keep.  
Samantha, treasure hunter,  
drifts toward other shores,  
where bargains still wear their modest price tags  
like forgotten miracles.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘Not an attractive place to shop’: how Poundland lost its appeal to shoppers “It’s not actually that cheap any more. It’s kind of lost its appeal because everything is not a pound.” Samantha, a shopper outside Poundland’s Luton retail park outlet who is heading off to B&M to find some better deals, sums up the feelings of many of her fellow bargain hunters and a central problem facing the new owner of the budget retailer.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
